title: Children in War Zones 1945-2025
description: Historical collection of images and descriptions of children affected by armed conflicts

wars.description: Some children, survivors of the Auschwitz concentration camp, emerge from their barracks shortly after liberation. Poland, after January 27, 1945 / On the 27th of January 1945, Auschwitz is liberated. Months later, WWII will end. Children were especially vulnerable to Nazi persecution.  As many as 1.5 million Jewish children alone were murdered or died at the hands of Nazi officials or their collaborators.

The Greek Civil War (1946-1949) created conditions whereby children were removed from their homes out of war zones and into neighbouring Eastern European countries. The result was that approximately 28,000 children crossed the borders in Eastern European countries during the course of the Civil War.

1950: A student in Suwon prepares to drink her daily ration of milk, provided by UNICEF ( UNICEF/UNI43171/Fowler Republic of Korea) / It is estimated over 100,000 Korean children were orphaned or displaced during the Korean War, separated from their parents by death, geography and poverty.
The Arab-Israeli conflict of 1967 created new waves of Palestinian refugees. Many children found themselves in refugee camps, where they would spend decades of their lives without a stable home.

Napalm Girl, June 8, 1972, Nick Ut / The picture captured the trauma and indiscriminate violence of a conflict that claimed, by some estimates, a million or more civilian lives. Officially titled “The Terror of War,” the photo is better known by the nickname given to the badly burned, naked 9-year-old at its center.
wars.estimated_affected: c.a. 84,000 war deaths among children (under age 15)
sources: Charles Hirschman, Samuel Preston, and Vu Manh Loi. 1995. “Vietnamese Casualties During the American War.” Population and Development Review 21: 783-812.

wars.description: The Soviet invasion of Afghanistan began a conflict that would mark generations of Afghan children. Many fled to refugee camps in Pakistan, where they grew up never knowing peace.
The war between Iran and Iraq tragically involved children as civilian victims of city bombings. Both countries used child soldiers, violating children's rights.

During the Rwandan genocide, approximately 300,000 children were orphaned in just 100 days. Many witnessed unimaginable violence, while others were forced to participate in killings or flee to neighboring countries.
The conflict in Kosovo forced hundreds of thousands of Albanian children to flee their homes. Refugee camps in Macedonia and Albania hosted entire families who had lost everything.

The invasion of Afghanistan after September 11th added new trauma to generations of Afghan children already marked by decades of war. Many schools were destroyed and access to education became even more limited.
The 2003 invasion of Iraq exposed millions of Iraqi children to violence, displacement, and infrastructure destruction. Access to clean water, food, and medical care became precarious.

The beginning of the Syrian civil war marked the start of one of the most severe humanitarian crises of the 21st century. Syrian children became the most vulnerable, with millions forced to flee and deprived of education.

The expansion of ISIS led to severe violations of children's rights, including forced recruitment, slavery, and public executions. Yazidi children were particularly affected by genocide and trafficking.
The Russian invasion of Ukraine forced millions of Ukrainian children to flee their homes. Many lived in basements during bombings, while others were forcibly deported to Russia.
The civil war in Sudan severely affected children, with approximately 14 million minors in need of humanitarian assistance. Many schools were destroyed or used as shelters for displaced people.

The escalation of conflict in October 2023 continued to severely affect children in Gaza throughout 2024. Many lost parents, homes, and access to essential services in one of the world's most densely populated territories.

In 2025, it is estimated that over 450 million children live in active conflict zones worldwide. Conflicts in Ukraine, Sudan, Afghanistan, Syria, and Gaza continue to represent the main humanitarian crises affecting childhood.

metadata.notes: Estimates of affected children are approximate and based on multiple sources. Actual numbers could be significantly higher due to the difficulty of collecting accurate data during conflicts.
